Award.AbstractNarration:
The concept of gentrification -- where middle or high income residents displace poorer residents within a particular region -- is relatively well studied in cities and urban settings. It is commonly used to describe economic, demographic, and cultural change in such environments. Gentrification in rural areas and areas with lower population densities is much less well studied. As America's rural landscape undergoes significant social and economic transformations, it will become increasingly important to understand the factors underlying these changes. In this project, scholars from the United States, the United Kingdom, and France will investigate whether rural changes in these three countries can be explained by the concept of rural gentrification. The three countries to be studied in this project are of particular interest because there are some important differences from one country to the next that will allow the researchers to test different hypotheses concerning social and economic change in rural settings. In terms of intellectual merit, this project will add to the theoretical understanding of gentrification as it plays out in different spatial contexts and situate interpretations of rural gentrification from different national contexts within the literatures on asset-based theorizations of social stratification, urban gentrification, and social capital in rural development. In terms of broader impacts, this project will produce key understandings that will be beneficial to rural development professionals and rural residents. Given the aging population in many advanced economies and the relationship between aging and migration to rural areas, forces of rural gentrification are likely to accelerate in the coming years. Therefore, knowledge of the extent of and processes behind rural gentrification across national contexts will be critical for future planning.

The researchers will employ a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods to better understand whether rural gentrification is capable of explaining the form and dynamics of rural change across the United States, the United Kingdom, and France. The work will consist of (1) content and discourse analyses to understand how the concept of gentrification is used in the literatures in the three countries, (2) interviews with residents to develop a conceptualization of social assets employed within processes of rural gentrification, and (3) mappings and analyses of the geographies of rural gentrification in the three countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This cross-national comparative analysis of rural gentrification revealed unique geographies of the process. First, the spatial extent of rural gentrification was highly uneven both between and within the three countries. For example, in the United States, rural gentrification was extensive in the New England, Mountain, and Pacific census divisions. In contrast, in the United Kingdom, the phenomenon is most concentrated a single region, the Southeast areas surrounding London and much less common in other parts of the country. The comparative analysis also highlighted how rural gentrification varies in unique ways along the rural-urban continuum. In France 90% of rural areas closely connected to large urban cores showed evidence of gentrification, yet in the United States only 60% of similarly connected rural areas were undergoing gentrification. Unique to the United States, 50% of the most isolated rural communities showed evidence of gentrification whereas in France only 30% of isolated rural communities were gentrifying.

The US Case Studies also brought new understandings of rural gentrification.

  • Jackson, Wyoming – a classic example of the process – revealed how rural gentrification is spilling over into neighboring communities in both Wyoming and Idaho. In addition, this case study highlighted how ‘super’ gentrification in the region is fueled by external sources of capital, as private equity and hedge funds become important players in shaping the gentrified rural landscape.
  • Gentrification in The Mad River Valley of Vermont is tied to unique elements of the Valley’s history. Counter-culturalist baby boomers in the 1960s and 70s first moved to the region as part of the back-to-the-land movement, yet many moved away as they entered middle age. Today, many of these boomers are returning as agents of gentrification in later phases of their lives. Second, the Mad River Valley experienced a construction boom during the late 1970s and 1980s as Sugarbush Ski Area expanded its operations. Today, these hastily built ski homes from the 70s and 80s provide an ample supply of gentrifiable property in the Valley. Given their age and the poor construction, upon purchase, these homes often require significant renovations and upgrades resulting in a newly gentrified housing stock.
  • The Finger Lakes case study reveals what are possibly the three most interesting results from the project. First, situated on the rural-urban interface within a larger metropolitan region, rural gentrification underway in the Finger Lakes is tied to larger processes of economic restructuring underway in the larger metropolitan region and rust belt more broadly. Specifically, manufacturing decline in Rochester, New York has eliminated many well-paying blue-collar jobs, and workers in these jobs often had summer cottages/camps throughout the Finger Lakes. Without these jobs, the tax burden of the summer homes becomes difficult forcing many to sell their old rustic lakefront homes releasing a supply of housing stock that is the target of gentrification. In this way, the rural gentrification in the Finger Lakes becomes intrinsically linked to economic transformations operating at larger regional, national, and global scales. Second, the Finger Lakes case study documented examples of diverse physical forms of rural gentrification similar in many ways to work done in urban areas. Third, the diverse physical forms of rural gentrification visually apparent to any person passing through the region coincide with new temporal rhythms surrounding the uses of these newly gentrified spaces. Respondents indicate gentrified second homes are used less frequently than older more rustic cabins and cottages, yet simultaneously at times gentrification coincides with a transition from seasonal to year-round use. Thus, gentrification in the Finger Lakes reveals that the physical transformations are layered on top of new diverse temporal rhythms in the ways the gentrified spaces are lived in and used.
  • The Michigan case study identified a pool of professional return migrants (teachers, lawyers, accountants, etc.) who were initiating processes of gentrification. These individuals/households typically had left the area as young adults and decided recently to return for reasons related to quality of life and childrearing. While certainly not affluent to the extent of rural gentrifiers in the Jackson Hole region, these individuals/households arrived with assets accumulated in urban labor and housing markets as well as strong social ties to the region. Return migration is a phenomenon not commonly invoked in the existing rural gentrification scholarship, yet this demographic phenomenon has produced a pool of potential gentrifiers reshaping the region.
  • Last in several case study locations (Mad River Valley, Finger Lakes, Upper Peninsula of Michigan, Northern Arizona, and the Greater Yellowstone Region), a share of the gentrifiers have little or no historical residential connection to the area, but rather were introduced, quite often at very young ages, to the areas by family vacation/recreation. Thus, long-standing vacation and recreation opportunities in these areas provide the initial point of contact for the majority of subsequent gentrifiers.
